questions.question_text: What are two components of the posture requirement when configuring Cisco ISE posture? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
The given answer is correct (Conditions and Remediation actions)
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-documents/ise-posture-prescriptive-deployment-guide/ta-p/3680273
Check the video: "Posture Requirements"

Also for me this is correct. 

The flow is really specific the first two options are conditions and remediations.
If we think in a logical way step by step this makes sense because the first thing that I have to configure are the conditions for have a compliant host in the network, the second step is that if a client is not compliant the client needs to solves that so we need to configure remediations also.

This settings are available in the policy elements page.

After that the client is compliant then you configure the policies for let the client have a specific result.

Selected Answer: BE
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/3-0/admin_guide/b_ISE_admin_3_0/b_ISE_admin_30_compliance.html#task_52F2E45628EF43C889B5559AF657B884
Create Client Posture Requirements
You can create a requirement in the Requirements window where you can associate user-defined conditions and Cisco defined conditions, and remediation actions. Once created and saved in the Requirements window, user-defined conditions and remediation actions can be viewed from their respective list windows.

comments.content:
Incorrect, see: https://youtu.be/kmS6_SxDYMY?list=PLvBZXH_IO6nDoVkUGcovsjwl8jF1c1ifv
answer: Conditions and Remediation actions

discussion.content:
The correct answer is:
https://community.cisco.com/t5/security-documents/ise-posture-prescriptive-deployment-guide/ta-p/3680273

Posture Configuration Flow
Configuring posture assessment in ISE requires several components to be taken into consideration: Conditions, Remediations, Requirements, Posture Policy, Client Provisioning and Access Policy. 

Conditions and Acces Policy

questions.question_text: Which term refers to an endpoint agent that tries to join an 802.1X-enabled network?

discussion.content:
Since ISE 1.2, 8909 is no longer used. Correct answer is 8905!

https://community.cisco.com/t5/network-access-control/port-8905-and-or-8909/td-p/3499402

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
The answer is -TCP 8905.

Cisco ISE uses TCP port 8905 for native supplicant provisioning of a Windows laptop. This port is used to communicate with the supplicant on the laptop and to provision it with the necessary settings to connect to the network.

The other ports are not used for native supplicant provisioning. TCP port 8909 is used for posture assessment, TCP port 443 is used for the Cisco ISE web interface, and UDP port 1812 is used for RADIUS authentication.

Selected Answer: A
Definately A, I doubt that we are being tested on ISE 1.2 anymore

questions.question_text: Which port does Cisco ISE use for native supplicant provisioning of a Windows laptop?
What must match between Cisco ISE and the network access device to successfully authenticate endpoints?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
as explained in the guide book 300-715 P114, a two node deployment is a distributed mode

Selected Answer: A
Avec 2 noeuds, nous sommes en mode standalone avec 1 noeud PAN/MNT primary et l'autre noeud PAN/MNT secondary

Selected Answer: B
You cannot have 2 Nodes in a deployment with the Standalone role, it needs to be Primary and Secondary => B) Distributed

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer. with 2 nodes, we have PAN/MNT/PSN on the same node. the second has PAN/MNT/PSN and PAN/MNT is secondary.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct--Any deployment that includes MORE than one node is a distributed deployment; hence the name "standalone"

questions.question_text: What is the deployment mode when two Cisco ISE nodes are configured in an environment?
